items.title: Options --disable-gpu and --ignore-gpu-blacklist don't work ðŸ¤”
items.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

### Steps to Reproduce

1. MacBook Pro (15-inch, Early 2011)
2. I'm trying to disable using High Perf. GPU.
```bash
open /Applications/Atom.app/ --args --disable-gpu --ignore-gpu-blacklist
```
It doesn't work.

But for Google Chrome it works fine
```bash
open /Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/ --args --disable-gpu --ignore-gpu-blacklist
```

**Expected behavior:**

Use Intel HD Graphics 3000 to have low energy impact. 

**Actual behavior:**

Atom uses High Perf. AMD Radeon HD 6490M having high energy impact.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%

### Versions

atom --version
Atom    : 1.31.1
Electron: 2.0.7
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

apm --version
apm  2.1.1
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.31.1
python 2.7.15
git 2.19.2

OS: 64bit Mac OS X 10.13.6 17G3025

### Additional Information

Usual Google Chrome:
![screen shot 2018-11-29 at 21 50 53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2473081/49245923-bce62700-f424-11e8-840d-235a0c11e35c.png)

Google Chrome disabled GPU:
![screen shot 2018-11-29 at 21 53 10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2473081/49245964-d2f3e780-f424-11e8-85ce-a0eb5cd5eb76.png)

Trying to disable GPU in Atom:
![screen shot 2018-11-29 at 22 08 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2473081/49245997-e69f4e00-f424-11e8-90eb-cdd0cca4d83c.png)

items.title: [THEME|One Dark] PHP return types on closures aren't themed
items.body:
### Description

The return types on closures in PHP files don't theme

### Steps to Reproduce

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16328050/49185154-525fb900-f348-11e8-8b32-cebd3ad55aad.png)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

`: string` should be themed.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

`: string` isn't themed, like `: void` in the method return type.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

All the time.

### Versions

1.26.1

items.title: Dart Support
items.body: I think it would be helpful for Atom to support Dart with it becoming more popular because of Flutter. Currently I just set the language to java because it brings some color labels to the code.

items.title: The event-stream incident and Atom's response
items.body:
As [reported this week][npm-report], a person socially-engineered the takeover of the Node flatmap-stream package and injected code that, through a series of detailed steps targeted at a very specific environment, tries to steal an end-user's bitcoin wallet. The Atom team has completed our investigation into whether any repository in the [atom organization][atom] uses or includes the compromised version of the package. We wanted to document what we did so that people using Atom or any of the code in our organization can understand if they might have been affected and how.

In our investigation, the only repository that referenced flatmap-stream was https://github.com/atom/flight-manual.atom.io. But it never referenced the malicious version of that package and would not affect users of the Flight Manual website hosted at https://flight-manual.atom.io. People who [locally compiled the Atom Flight Manual][compile] _could_ be affected if they manually updated to use the malicious version of flatmap-stream, v0.1.1.

### Summary

1. If you're a normal user of Atom, this security vulnerability **does not** affect you
1. If you use the https://flight-manual.atom.io website, this security vulnerability **does not** affect you
1. If you develop content for the https://flight-manual.atom.io website **AND** have tested those changes locally recently **AND** use crypto-currency wallets from that same machine, this security vulnerability **might** affect you

If you have any questions, please post in [the discussion topic][topic] on the official Atom message board or contact the team by email at atom@github.com. You can also read [the detailed analysis from the npm team][npm-analysis].

[atom]: https://github.com/atom
[compile]: https://github.com/atom/flight-manual.atom.io#testing-changes-locally
[npm-analysis]: https://blog.npmjs.org/post/180565383195/details-about-the-event-stream-incident
[npm-report]: https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/737
[topic]: https://discuss.atom.io/t/the-event-stream-incident-and-the-atom-teams-response/60807

items.title: Support for Swift Language via Sourcekit-LSP
items.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

---

Keep in mind that Atom is highly customizable in a number of ways and we strongly prefer that you consider these options before filing this issue:

* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/basic-customization/: tweak Atom's configuration, styles, and keybindings.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/atom-packages/: install a community package.
* https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/: use the Atom API in your init script, to create a package, or to enhance an existing package.

If you're convinced that none of these options are appropriate for the feature you want, please explain why that's the case by completely filling out the issue template below.

Also note that the Atom team has finite resources so it's unlikely that we'll work on feature requests. If we're interested in a particular feature however, we'll follow up and ask you to submit an RFC to talk about it in more detail.

-->

## Summary
[SourceKit-LSP](https://github.com/apple/sourcekit-lsp)

Implementaton of Swift Support using Sourcekit-LSP

# SourceKit-LSP

SourceKit-LSP is an implementation of the [Language Server Protocol](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/) (LSP) for Swift and C-based languages. It provides features like code-completion and jump-to-definition to editors that support LSP. SourceKit-LSP is built on top of [sourcekitd](https://github.com/apple/swift/tree/master/tools/SourceKit) and [clangd](https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clangd.html) for high-fidelity language support, and provides a powerful source code index as well as cross-language support. SourceKit-LSP supports projects that use the Swift Package Manager.

## Motivation

Support for Swift Language

items.title: Pending Pane not closing automatically
items.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I am using the pending pane feature pretty regularly and after some update (not sure anymore if it was atom itself or some packages) the pending panes won't close anymore. It just creates more tabs with italic titles.

**IMPORTANT**
Using Safe-Mode closes pending panes again as expected.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Single click on file (opens pending pane)
2. Single click on a different file (opens another pending pane)
3. Repeat to get new tabs all over the place.

**Expected behavior:** 
First pending pane dissappears and a new one with the new file opens.

**Actual behavior:**
A second pending pane gets opened, now there are two tabs with italic titles.

**Reproduces how often:**
100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.32.2
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3

Microsoft Windows 10 v1803

### Additional Information

None.

items.title: Tree-sitter code fold markers out of sync
items.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On nightly, the code fold arrows in the line gutter remain in place, even when the text changes line. These arrows no longer do anything.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a JS file
2. Make something foldable
```js
function foo() {
  
}
```
3. Confirm it folds normally, and unfold
4. Insert a newline at the start of the first line
5. Try to fold the function again

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Fold marker shifts with text

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Fold marker stayed in top line

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

1.34.0-nightly18

### Additional Information

/cc @maxbrunsfeld 

This was in safe mode, so I'm 99% sure it's not caused by me messing with the folding logic (which I am currently massacring).

Also, am I using the label right? It's not in Beta / Stable yet, so no panic. I checked CONTRIBUTING.md, but it doesn't have explanations of the latest labels.

items.title: Syntax Grammar matches incorrect file
items.body:
### Description
We have a [grammar for Singularity recipe files](https://github.com/singularityhub/language-singularity) and are having a hard time matching a file type called "Singularity.*" (starting with Singularity, and matching *just* Singularity or Singularity with some extension. [Here](https://github.com/singularityhub/language-singularity/blob/master/grammars/singularity.cson) is the cson grammar file, and specifically this doesn't seem to work:

```yaml
'fileTypes': [
    'Singularity'
    'def'
]
```
We have also tried Singularity.* but it leads to the wrong behavior in both cases. For these cases, what happens is that it recognized *all* files as Singularity after a save action (see the [issue here](https://github.com/singularityhub/language-singularity/issues/4#issuecomment-441269492)). Could you please help? Thank you!

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install the grammer
2. Create a file called Singularity and save it
3. Create other recipe files (Singularity.tag) and regular files

**Expected behavior:**
The Singularity and Singularity.tag should be highlighted

**Actual behavior:**
All files are highlighted

**Reproduces how often:** 
Always

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Versions

```bash
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.32.1
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
Node    : 8.9.3
```
```bash
$ apm --version
apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.1
python 3.6.4
git 2.7.4
```

### Additional Information

@tsnowlan can provide additional context, as he was helping with the issue [here](https://github.com/singularityhub/language-singularity/issues/4#issuecomment-441269492)

items.body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description I just updated my Atom editor to version 1.32.2 on osx 10.13.6 and the highlighting of my javascript code broke. items.title: `e` key stuck as causing backspace
items.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x]  Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

### Description

I am using the atom editor in a remote (X2Go) session and it has started causing the `e` key to enter `backspace`.  I'm not sure how it started but have tried everything to revert the behaviour.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. reinstall atom - `apt purge atom && rm - r ~/.atom && apt install atom`
2. start atom (safe mode also causes issue)
3. type some characters and then `e` and `e` will work as a backspace

Other programs (including text editors, e.g. Leafpad) type the `e` as normal.
I have tried rebooting, restarting the session and the X2Go connection.

**Expected behavior:** 
- `e` should type `e`!

**Actual behavior:** 
- `e` behaves as backspace

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
- always

### Versions

Debian 9

Atom: 1.32.2
Electron 2.0.9
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node: 8.93

apm 2.1.2
npm 6.2.0
python 2.7.12
git 2.11.0

items.title: Ok, thanks for reporting back. We'll be releasing Atom 1.32.0 (stable) shortly, which will contain the same fix.

items.title: dev-live-reload package overwriting arbitrary styles
items.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites
Note: The problem has not been reproduced in Safe Mode for reasons that will become clear in the reproduction steps.
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I've been working on a ui theme called [cream-soda-ui](https://atom.io/themes/cream-soda-ui) and, after publishing an early version of it, issues have been opened up about some color problems making certain elements unreadable. After opening my theme in dev mode everything looked normal until the styles were reloaded. 

Upon styles reloading, either through saving whatever .less file I was working on or choosing "Reload All Styles" from the menu, various styles were arbitrarily overwritten with values whose source I can't isolate. As far as I can tell, only things to do with colors are overwritten. If I restart Atom (again in dev mode), everything goes back to normal until the styles are reloaded by dev-live-reload. 

I've inspected elements before reloading, noted their values (which were as expected compared to the default colors specified in the associated package's styles, settings-view or [deprecation-cop](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/packages/deprecation-cop/styles/deprecation-cop.less) for example). Where the default styles on deprecation-cop's `.deprecation-cop` class are:
```
.deprecation-cop {
  overflow: auto;
  -webkit-flex: 1;
  background-color: @app-background-color;
}
/*
  In cream-soda's case, 
  @base-background-color: #1c0604; (a rather dark brown)
  @app-background-color: darken(@base-background-color, 5%);
*/
```
after reloading, the inspector shows:
```
.deprecation-cop {
  overflow: auto;
  -webkit-flex: 1;
  background-color: #fff !important;
}
```

The problem is, none of my theme's styles use `!important`, none of my ui variables have a value of `#fff`, and the deprecation cop package styles don't use either of these. As mentioned above, the background color of the deprecation cop div should be a rather dark brown but instead it's turned white and the only way to overwrite it is to use an `!important` rule to counter the one that seems to appear out of nowhere.

I have disabled all packages except those bundled with Atom and the problem persists.

The only package I have symlinked to -dev is my theme.

The most substantial, potentially relevant changes made to my Atom install are probably installing atom ide and nuclide, largely to address readability issues brought up by users that were specific to UI elements added by those packages.

I would very much like to make this theme generally better in every respect but I'm extremely hesitant to work on it when I can't be totally sure if I'm unnecessarily fighting with styles that only exist because of a bug. Any wisdom or insight would be most appreciated.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a UI theme-in-progress in Dev Mode such that making changes to the files in the project folder should cause updates to the UI.
2. Open a non-editor tab. I noticed the problems in many places but to keep things simple look try deprecation-cop, GitHub, and settings-view.
3. Click: Packages > Dev Live Reload > Reload All Styles
4. Rub your temples firmly, but not so firmly as to cause any harm.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Arbitrary styles are overwritten; typically colors for text, backgrounds, and borders; typically with `#fff` or `#ffffff`.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
Electron: 2.0.9
Chrome  : 61.0.3163.100
apm  2.1.2
npm  6.2.0
node 8.9.3 x64
atom 1.32.2
python 3.7.0b3
git 2.18.0.windows.1
visual studio 2013

### Screenshot examples
#### The Deprecation Cop tab before:
![deprecationcop_onstartup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31920334/48830308-479e9600-ed42-11e8-9a5c-1c91ca8440a5.PNG)
#### After:
![deprecationcop_stylereload](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31920334/48830348-600eb080-ed42-11e8-8de7-52c10adb9b2d.PNG)

#### The GitHub tab before:
![gittabinspected_onstartup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31920334/48829827-3b660900-ed41-11e8-9aaf-997aa12b9cd3.PNG)
#### After:
![gittabinspected_stylereload](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31920334/48829831-3d2fcc80-ed41-11e8-8bf8-b2f738d0e06b.PNG)

### Prerequisites

### Description

Tree View has several bugs when used using keyboard:
(1) When browsing through files with keyboard's up and down arrows the currently highlighted file is NOT shown in preview mode in Editor pane or if there is already active tab with that file opened - it should be then made as selected - this is exactly the behavior when you highlight file with a mouse click.

(2) When clicking fn+Up or fn+Down (on mac) scroll is going PgUp or PgDwn but the file selected is NOT changed. Cursor/currently highlighte/selected file should follow scroll in that case. This is exactly how Editor pane is behaving

### Steps to Reproduce

Check description.

**Expected behavior:** In description.

**Actual behavior:** In description.

items.title: Cannot open file from inside atom if it is part of gitignore
items.body:
### Description

It's more like a question because it seems to be a feature, but I am not sure why it works the way it does.

My project is on git, and I have some files that are ignored from the git repo. So whenever I open the command bar (Cmd+P) and start typing the name of the file, it does not show on the list. Shouldn't the autocompletion works for all files in the project? why does it ignore those files that are ignored by git?

The only way to open those files it to use explorer/finder to drag and drop them into atom or open manually. Git ignore files are also not showin in the file tree, maybe there is a shortcut to enable showing all files in the treeview, regardless of whether they are part of git repo or not?

items.title: Scope of cursor at end of line
items.body:
### Description

The scope of the cursor is taken to be of the character to the right of it. This works most of the time, but can have unexpected behaviour when the cursor is at the end of a line and scopes do not extend to the newline character.

E.g., in [this issue](https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/issues/1006) the TS parser does not count the newline as part of the comment, so autocomplete suggestions were not suppressed when typing at the end of the line. I raised [this issue](https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter-javascript/issues/87) to suggest a fix, but decided this is more general than comments.

I think Atom should in general use the left character if the next is a newline. This behaviour matches the TextMate grammars, but I'm not sure if that's because they apply the scope to the newline character or because they already do this.

It potentially makes the following confusing, but it also makes sense in a way (and matches TextMate behaviour, so not really confusing at all). Here, `|` is the cursor (not a character), and the scopes are how TextMate handles it
```js
// End of line: 'source string' 
"foo"|

// Not end of line: 'source'
"foo"| bar 
```

/cc @maxbrunsfeld This falls under Tree-sitter, and I've made my argument.

items.title: Ruby syntax of theme not being applied correctly
items.body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: https://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Started Atom yesterday, no [known] changes or updates to any packages, however I did update OSX to 10.14.1 I use the [One Dark syntax](https://github.com/atom/one-dark-syntax), and noticed immediately that all of my method calls were blue, instead of white. There have been no changes to the One Dark Syntax theme. I have tried manually changing my `styles.less` with the following, [using the CSS from the official one-dark-syntax repo ](https://github.com/atom/one-dark-syntax/blob/master/styles/syntax/_base.less) ```css .syntax--punctuation { &.syntax--section { &.syntax--method, &.syntax--class, &.syntax--inner-class { color:hsl(220, 14%, 71%) !important; } } } ``` This had no impact. I'm thinking this could be an issue with the way the ruby is being parsed. ### Steps to Reproduce Unable to test on another device (only have one Mac!), but happens every time no matter what I try, including safe mode and switching to another theme and back again ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.32.2 Electron: 2.0.9 Chrome : 61.0.3163.100 Node : 8.9.3 ``` ### Additional Information This screenshot shows what it should look like (from a copycat theme for sublime) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9802420/48708168-b3291c00-ebf9-11e8-9a63-1a6f1d826154.png)

items.title: Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '~/AppData\Local\atom\app-1.32.2\wp-boot...
items.body:

**Atom**: 1.32.2 x64
**Electron**: 2.0.9
**OS**: Microsoft Windows 10 Home
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
